skill.name: theater-detection-audit
skill.description: Performs comprehensive audits to detect placeholder code, mock data, TODO markers, and incomplete implementations in codebases. Use this skill when you need to find all instances of "theater" in code such as hardcoded mock responses, stub functions, commented-out production logic, or fake data that needs to be replaced with real implementations. The skill systematically identifies these instances, reads their full context, and completes them with production-quality code.

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing workflow guidelines for detecting placeholder code. No executable code, network access, filesystem operations, or command execution capabilities exist. All 33 static findings are false positives caused by the scanner matching English words in documentation (like audit, encrypt, integrity, scan, auth) as cryptographic or security-related patterns. The skill is purely a prompt-based guidance document.

content.user_title: Detect placeholder code and mocks in codebases
content.value_statement: Codebases often contain placeholder code, mock data, and stub implementations that appear functional but are not production-ready. This skill systematically identifies all instances of theater and provides a workflow to replace them with production-quality code.
actual_capabilities: Detects mock data and hardcoded responses
Identifies TODO, FIXME, HACK, and XXX markers
Finds stub functions and empty implementations
limitations: Does not execute code or modify files directly
Scope limited to pattern detection within provided context

use_cases.title: Prepare code for production
use_cases.description: Audit codebases before release to ensure all mocks, stubs, and placeholders are replaced with real implementations.

use_cases.title: Identify fake functionality
use_cases.description: Detect code that appears to work but uses hardcoded data or simplified logic that will fail in production.

use_cases.title: Understand real vs placeholder
use_cases.description: When joining a project, quickly identify which code is production-ready and which areas need work.

prompt_templates.title: Basic audit request
prompt_templates.prompt: Use theater-detection-audit skill to scan my codebase for placeholder code, mock data, TODO markers, and incomplete implementations. Report all findings with file paths and line numbers.

prompt_templates.title: Production prep
prompt_templates.prompt: Run a theater-detection-audit on my project to ensure no mocks or stubs remain before production deployment. Prioritize findings by risk level.

prompt_templates.title: Legacy code audit
prompt_templates.prompt: Use theater-detection-audit to identify all instances of hardcoded responses, stub functions, and commented-out code in my inherited codebase. Provide a completion roadmap.

prompt_templates.title: Quality gate
prompt_templates.prompt: Execute theater-detection-audit to verify no new placeholder code has been introduced. Flag any new TODO or FIXME markers that require attention.

best_practices: Run theater detection before every production release
Prioritize high-risk theater (auth, payments, data validation) first
Document deferred theater with clear completion timelines
anti_patterns: Deploying code with unresolved TODO markers in critical paths
Assuming hardcoded test data works with real production inputs
Skipping theater audit during rapid prototyping phases

faq.question: What programming languages does this skill support?
faq.answer: The skill works with any language. Pattern detection is text-based and language-agnostic.

faq.question: How long does a full audit take?
faq.answer: Audit time depends on codebase size. Plan 5-10 minutes for small repos, longer for large monorepos.

faq.question: Can this skill fix detected theater automatically?
faq.answer: No. The skill identifies theater and provides recommendations. Manual implementation of fixes is required.

faq.question: Does this skill access my network or files?
faq.answer: No. The skill is purely prompt-based guidance. It does not execute code or access external systems.

faq.question: What is the difference between theater and technical debt?
faq.answer: Theater specifically refers to non-functional placeholder code. Technical debt may include working but suboptimal code.

faq.question: How does this compare to functionality-audit skill?
faq.answer: Theater detection finds fake placeholder code. Functionality-audit verifies that real code actually works correctly.
